misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a road trip cost calculator rather than a number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100, repeated guessing, and high/low feedback. None of the required game logic (randomness, loop for guesses, comparison to secret number, or termination on correct guess) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute and print the cost of driving based on distance, MPG, and price per gallon, instead of implementing an interactive number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they match the secret number, and after each incorrect guess print whether the guess was too high or too low, finally reporting the number of guesses when correct.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of a guess between 1 and 100
No use of Random or generation of a secret number
No loop to allow multiple guesses
No conditional logic to print 'Too high' or 'Too low'
Program terminates after a single cost calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem statement or mixing it up with a different exercise about computing trip cost.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program around a secret random number and repeated user guesses, using a Random object, a loop for input, and if/else checks to compare the guess to the secret number.
related_concepts: Loops and conditionals for interactive input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code is devoted to a trip cost calculator and there is no trace of number guessing game logic, so it is very likely the student implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: This full program calculates driving cost and never generates a random number, prompts for guesses, or provides 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback as required by the number guessing game specification.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Address Prompt Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different task (Road Trip Cost Calculation) instead of the required Number Guessing Game. Consequently, the submission lacks fundamental components like random number generation, looping structures, and conditional logic for hints.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code addresses the requirements of Question 2 (Number Guessing Game).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must implement a loop structure, generate a random target number, accept repeated user input, and provide directional hints (Too high/Too low) until the correct number is guessed.
symptoms: Code implements cost calculation rather than game logic
Missing random number generation
Missing main control loop (while/do-while)
Variables are irrelevant to the game (distance, mpg, price)
misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted the incorrect file or code from an unrelated assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description for Q2 and submit the Java code that implements the Number Guessing Game described.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to solving an entirely different, identifiable problem (economic calculation), confirming a total failure to meet the requirements of the Number Guessing Game.

evidence.note: The class name indicates an entirely different purpose than a Number Guessing Game.

evidence.snippet: System.out.print("Enter the driving distance in miles: ");
evidence.note: The input prompts are for geographic/economic variables, not for number guessing.
The core calculation solves the road trip cost problem, not the random number game.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (Road Trip Cost calculator) instead of the required Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may have submitted the wrong file or confused which assignment they were working on.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submission should contain a Number Guessing Game that generates a random number between 1-100, prompts the user to guess, and provides feedback until the correct answer is reached.
symptoms: Code reads driving distance, MPG, and price per gallon
Code calculates and outputs fuel cost
No random number generation
No guessing loop
No 'Too high' or 'Too low' logic
Program name is 'RoadTripCost' not 'NumberGuessingGame'
misconceptions.root_cause: File management error or assignment confusion - student submitted an entirely different program.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify you are submitting the correct file for Q2. Start over with the Number Guessing Game requirements: use Random to generate a number 1-100, use a loop to accept guesses, and compare each guess to provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code implements a completely different algorithm (fuel cost calculation) with no elements of the Number Guessing Game requirements.

evidence.note: Entire program implements road trip cost calculation, not the number guessing game specified in Q2.

misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem instead of the number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator rather than the required number guessing game, so none of the specified game behaviors (random number, guessing loop, high/low hints, correct-guess termination) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit any working Java program that uses user input and arithmetic, even if it does not match the described number guessing behavior.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must specifically implement the described number guessing game: generate a random number between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess, give 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback on incorrect guesses, and stop when the guess is correct while reporting the number of guesses.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of guesses between 1 and 100.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop to allow repeated guesses.
No conditional logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' messages.
No termination condition based on a correct guess.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or misunderstanding that the program must match the exact problem specification, not just be any correct Java program.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design your program around its exact requirements: decide what inputs and outputs are needed for a number guessing game, then implement random number generation, a guessing loop, and conditional feedback.
related_concepts: Program design for interactive console applications
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program implements a different, self-contained task (road trip cost calculation) with no traces of number guessing game logic, indicating a systematic mismatch with the problem requirements.

evidence.note: The code implements a road trip cost calculator, not a number guessing game. There is no random number, no guessing loop, and no high/low feedback as required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: Completely incorrect program implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for a completely different problem (calculating road trip cost) than the one assigned (Number Guessing Game). This means none of the required features related to the assigned task are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment, RoadTripCost, instead of the required Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student needs to write a program that initializes a random number, prompts the user repeatedly for guesses, compares the guess to the actual number, and provides 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints until the guess is correct.
symptoms: Code has unrelated logic (distance, mpg, price inputs and cost calculation).
The file/class name (RoadTripCost) indicates a different intent.
None of the required functionality (random number generation, loops, conditionals for high/low) for the Number Guessing Game exists.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding the assignment prompt or submitting the wrong file/code block.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for the Number Guessing Game and write a program specifically for that task. Ensure you initialize a random number, use a loop to manage guesses, and employ conditional statements to provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code calculates 'Road Trip Cost' based on user inputs, which is entirely unrelated to a 'Number Guessing Game'.

evidence.note: The entire program implements a cost calculation, not the number guessing game.
